qas.question: The Ottomans were portrayed as what?
Who is known as the saint of all British colonial officers?
What did Charles George Gordon spend his time between?

answers.text: assignments living among the poor and donating his salary

qas.question: When did he win Ottoman confidence?

answers.text: as a junior officer in the Crimean War

qas.question: What did he become in his later career?

answers.text: a high official in the Ottoman Empire

context: This view reveals a somewhat less than altruistic Christian intent of the British Empire; however, it was paradoxical from the beginning, as Simpson and most other writers pointed out. The Ottomans were portrayed as <a0_0>the slavers<a0_0/>, but even as the American and British fleets were striking at the Barbary pirates on behalf of freedom, their countries were promulgating a vigorous African slave trade of their own. <a1_0>Charles George Gordon<a1_0/> is known as the saint of all British colonial officers. A dedicated Christian, he spent his time between <a2_0>assignments living among the poor and donating his salary<a2_0/> on their behalf. He won Ottoman confidence <a3_0>as a junior officer in the Crimean War<a3_0/>. In his later career he became <a4_0>a high official in the Ottoman Empire<a4_0/>, working as Governor of Egypt for the Ottoman khedive for the purpose of conducting campaigns against slavers and slavery in Egypt and the Sudan.
